articles.headline: Outside Collectors for I.R.S. Are Accused of Illegal Practices
articles.snippet: A group of Democratic senators obtained call scripts from companies collecting overdue tax debt and found what they said were a variety of abuses.
articles.abstract: A group of Democratic senators obtained call scripts from companies collecting overdue tax debt and found what they said were a variety of abuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Raid your 401(k). Ask your boss for a loan, load up on your credit cards, or put up your house as collateral by taking out a second mortgage.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Europe and Japan Near Trade Deal as U.S. Takes Protectionist Path
articles.snippet: The European Union and Japan are close to an agreement that would bring together two giants encompassing a quarter of the world’s economy.
articles.abstract: The European Union and Japan are close to an agreement that would bring together two giants encompassing a quarter of the world’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union and Japan are close to sealing one of the largest trade agreements ever, a deal that could further isolate the United States as President Trump forges a protectionist path.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: C.I.A. Set Up Secret Back Channel With Syria to Try to Free U.S. Hostage
articles.snippet: The Trump administration began searching early on for ways to free Austin Tice, a journalist who has been missing since 2012.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration began searching early on for ways to free Austin Tice, a journalist who has been missing since 2012.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the early days of the Trump administration, national security officials began exploring ways to free Austin Tice, an American journalist and a former Marine officer believed to be held by the Syrian government. His case has frustrated investigators and diplomats since he disappeared while on assignment nearly five years ago.

articles.headline: Mistrial in Cincinnati Shooting as Officer Is Latest Not to Be Convicted
articles.snippet: It was a second hung jury for Ray Tensing, the ex-officer charged in the death of Samuel DuBose during a botched traffic stop in 2015 in Cincinnati.
articles.abstract: It was a second hung jury for Ray Tensing, the ex-officer charged in the death of Samuel DuBose during a botched traffic stop in 2015 in Cincinnati.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — The encounters with the police officers turned deadly within seconds. Each time, a black man was fatally shot, and each time, it was captured on video. And three times in the span of a week, the officers’ trials have ended without a conviction.
articles.byline: By Jess Bidgood and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Planned Parenthood Battle Could Sway Fortunes of G.O.P. Health Bill
articles.snippet: Planned Parenthood, threatened with a cutoff of more than 40 percent of its funding, is mobilizing to bring down the Republican health care bill.
articles.abstract: Planned Parenthood, threatened with a cutoff of more than 40 percent of its funding, is mobilizing to bring down the Republican health care bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Senate barrels toward a vote next week to sever all federal support for Planned Parenthood, the 100-year-old organization is mobilizing furiously to bring down the Republicans’ broader legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act before it reaches President Trump’s desk.

articles.headline: Lessons From the Collapse of Banco Popular
articles.snippet: When Spain’s fifth-largest bank failed this month, Banco Santander swooped in to the rescue, and regulators breathed easy. They should have been scared.
articles.abstract: When Spain’s fifth-largest bank failed this month, Banco Santander swooped in to the rescue, and regulators breathed easy. They should have been scared.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banco Popular, Spain’s fifth-largest bank, with over $100 billion in loans, collapsed earlier this month, forcing it into the arms of its rival, Banco Santander. The latter, Spain’s largest bank, bought the failing institution for the nominal sum of one euro after depositors withdrew money en masse and the company’s stock price plunged.

articles.headline: Republican Senator Vital to Health Bill’s Passage Won’t Support It
articles.snippet: Senator Dean Heller of Nevada became the latest Republican to say he cannot support a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act in its current form.
articles.abstract: Senator Dean Heller of Nevada became the latest Republican to say he cannot support a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act in its current form.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Dean Heller of Nevada, perhaps the most vulnerable Republican facing re-election in 2018, said Friday that he would not support the Senate health care overhaul as written, dealing a serious blow to his party’s attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act just days before a showdown vote.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: From 9/11 to Orlando, Ken Feinberg’s Alter Ego in Compensating Victims
articles.snippet: Camille Biros has helped her small but influential law firm set up payment protocols tied to the BP oil spill, mass shootings and other catastrophes.
articles.abstract: Camille Biros has helped her small but influential law firm set up payment protocols tied to the BP oil spill, mass shootings and other catastrophes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn unveiled a program on Thursday to compensate victims of sexual abuse by its clergy, it chose a familiar name to oversee it: Kenneth R. Feinberg.

articles.headline: Maritime Mystery: Why a U.S. Destroyer Failed to Dodge a Cargo Ship
articles.snippet: Lookouts and radar operators on the destroyer Fitzgerald should have spotted the freighter it collided with, and the captain should have been wakened.
articles.abstract: Lookouts and radar operators on the destroyer Fitzgerald should have spotted the freighter it collided with, and the captain should have been wakened.
articles.lead_paragraph: There should have been lookouts on watch on the port, starboard and stern of the destroyer Fitzgerald — sailors scanning the horizon with binoculars and reporting by headsets to the destroyer’s bridge. At 1:30 a.m. last Saturday, off the coast of Japan south of Tokyo, they could hardly have failed to see the 730-foot freighter ACX Crystal, stacked with more than 1,000 containers, as it closed in.

articles.headline: Easiest Path to Riches on the Web? An Initial Coin Offering
articles.snippet: Programmers are selling digital currencies redeemable for services that do not exist. Where some see a financing revolution, others see trouble.
articles.abstract: Programmers are selling digital currencies redeemable for services that do not exist. Where some see a financing revolution, others see trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new crop of technology entrepreneurs is forgoing the usual routes to raising money. The entrepreneurs are not pitching venture capitalists, selling stock in an initial public offering or using crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter.

articles.headline: A Street Fight Among Grocers to Deliver Your Milk, Eggs, Bananas
articles.snippet: Bananas can’t get cold. Milk mustn’t tip. Online food delivery still trips up companies. A day on the truck shows why.
articles.abstract: Bananas can’t get cold. Milk mustn’t tip. Online food delivery still trips up companies. A day on the truck shows why.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every couple of days, Sinclair Browne fights through traffic in Times Square, squeezes his delivery truck into a parking spot, walks up four flights of stairs and delivers groceries to a guy whose order he knows by heart.

articles.headline: Why Grenfell Tower Burned: Regulators Put Cost Before Safety
articles.snippet: The incineration of the 24-story London high rise, the deadliest fire in Britain in more than a century, was rooted in a regulatory breakdown.
articles.abstract: The incineration of the 24-story London high rise, the deadliest fire in Britain in more than a century, was rooted in a regulatory breakdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The doorbell woke Yassin Adam just before 1 a.m. A neighbor was frantically alerting others on the fourth floor of Grenfell Tower about a fire in his apartment. “My fridge blew up,” the man shouted.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Danny Hakim and James Glanz

articles.headline: Health Law Repeal Leaves Nevada Republican Torn Between Lawmakers
articles.snippet: Senator Dean Heller could be a swing vote on his party’s health care bill. His majority leader wants his help. His governor wants him to bring it down.
articles.abstract: Senator Dean Heller could be a swing vote on his party’s health care bill. His majority leader wants his help. His governor wants him to bring it down.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Dean Heller, Republican of Nevada, is the man everyone wants. This has not been a good thing for him.

articles.headline: Is a Buddhist Group Changing China? Or Is China Changing It?
articles.snippet: Millions have joined faith organizations like Fo Guang Shan, aiming to fill what they see as a moral vacuum. But to operate in China, groups like Fo Guang Shan must compromise.
articles.abstract: Millions have joined faith organizations like Fo Guang Shan, aiming to fill what they see as a moral vacuum. But to operate in China, groups like Fo Guang Shan must compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: YIXING, China — For most of her life, Shen Ying was disappointed by the world she saw around her. She watched China’s economic rise in this small city in the Yangtze River Valley, and she found a foothold in the new middle class, running a convenience store in a strip mall. Yet prosperity felt hollow.

articles.headline: Commando Raids on ISIS Yield Vital Data in Shadowy War
articles.snippet: Risky Special Operations missions targeting midlevel figures can prove valuable for unearthing information about the Islamic State’s inner circle.
articles.abstract: Risky Special Operations missions targeting midlevel figures can prove valuable for unearthing information about the Islamic State’s inner circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One late afternoon in April, helicopter-borne American commandos intercepted a vehicle in southeastern Syria carrying a close associate of the Islamic State’s supreme leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

articles.headline: In Towns Already Hit by Steel Mill Closings, a New Casualty: Retail Jobs
articles.snippet: Thousands of workers face unemployment as retailers struggle to adapt to online shopping. But even as e-commerce grows, it isn’t absorbing these workers.
articles.abstract: Thousands of workers face unemployment as retailers struggle to adapt to online shopping. But even as e-commerce grows, it isn’t absorbing these workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHNSTOWN, Pa. — Dawn Nasewicz comes from a family of steelworkers, with jobs that once dominated the local economy. She found her niche in retail.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: For Grieving Parents, Trump Is ‘Speaking for the Dead’ on Immigration
articles.snippet: Their children died at the hands of undocumented immigrants, and their anguish forms the emotional cornerstone of the president’s signature issue.
articles.abstract: Their children died at the hands of undocumented immigrants, and their anguish forms the emotional cornerstone of the president’s signature issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: The families could reel off all the times they had called the media and written to Washington, but after all that trying, they had never heard anyone who mattered say anything like it: Most Mexican immigrants, Donald J. Trump declared in his first campaign speech, were “rapists” who were “bringing drugs, bringing crime” across the border.

articles.headline: Senate Leaders Try to Appease Members as Support for Health Bill Slips
articles.snippet: With criticism mounting over their bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, top Republicans are cutting deals and cajoling members to get to 50 votes.
articles.abstract: With criticism mounting over their bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, top Republicans are cutting deals and cajoling members to get to 50 votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republican leaders scrambled Sunday to rally support for their health care bill as opposition continued to build inside and outside Congress, and as several Republican senators questioned whether it would be approved this week.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Where Trump Zigs, Tillerson Zags, Putting Him at Odds With White House
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson has found himself out of sync, especially on Middle East policy, with President Trump and his top advisers Jared Kushner and Stephen K. Bannon.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson has found himself out of sync, especially on Middle East policy, with President Trump and his top advisers Jared Kushner and Stephen K. Bannon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Rex W. Tillerson, the former chief executive of Exxon Mobil, arrived in Washington five months ago to become the secretary of state, his boosters said he brought two valuable assets to a job that had usually gone to someone steeped in government and diplomacy: a long history managing a global company, and deep relationships from the Middle East to Russia that enabled him to close deals.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Gardiner Harris and Mark Landler

articles.headline: After Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis, Worries Shift to Virgin Islands
articles.snippet: With debts piling up and lenders growing nervous, the U.S. Virgin Islands is approaching the same kind of fiscal crisis that engulfed Puerto Rico.
articles.abstract: With debts piling up and lenders growing nervous, the U.S. Virgin Islands is approaching the same kind of fiscal crisis that engulfed Puerto Rico.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I. — The United States Virgin Islands is best known for its powdery beaches and turquoise bays, a constant draw for the tourists who frequent this tiny American territory.

articles.headline: Third Point, a Hedge Fund, Sets Its Activist Sights on Nestlé
articles.snippet: The fund, run by Daniel S. Loeb, has called on the Swiss food giant to sell its stake in L’Oréal and move more quickly to adapt to changing consumer tastes.
articles.abstract: The fund, run by Daniel S. Loeb, has called on the Swiss food giant to sell its stake in L’Oréal and move more quickly to adapt to changing consumer tastes.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Over the past two decades, the hedge fund mogul Daniel S. Loeb has established himself as one of the biggest activist investors around. Now, he has set his sights on one of Europe’s largest corporate citizens: Nestlé, the global food giant.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Takata, Unable to Overcome Airbag Crisis, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
articles.snippet: The Japanese company at the center of history’s farthest-reaching auto safety crisis said it would sell its assets to Key Safety Systems, a Chinese-owned American rival.
articles.abstract: The Japanese company at the center of history’s farthest-reaching auto safety crisis said it would sell its assets to Key Safety Systems, a Chinese-owned American rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Takata, the Japanese auto parts maker crippled by vast airbag recalls, filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States and Japan and said it would sell its surviving operations to a Chinese-owned American rival, Key Safety Systems.

articles.headline: At Cannes, the Great Gusher of Content Comes With Warning Signs
articles.snippet: The hottest ticket is your eyeballs, and every content creator and distributor wants them. Can the worst consequences be forestalled?
articles.abstract: The hottest ticket is your eyeballs, and every content creator and distributor wants them. Can the worst consequences be forestalled?
articles.lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — I imagine that covering the annual Cannes Lions advertising festival here is a little bit like covering the great Texas oil boom a century ago — only with better food, cocktails and scenery.

articles.headline: Yoplait Learns to Manufacture Authenticity to Go With Its Yogurt
articles.snippet: As Greek yogurt’s popularity soared, Yoplait struggled to market its own version. Then it decided to develop something else: a compelling story.
articles.abstract: As Greek yogurt’s popularity soared, Yoplait struggled to market its own version. Then it decided to develop something else: a compelling story.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, as the Yogurt Wars were heating up and Greek invaders were storming the grocery aisles, executives at Yoplait, one of the nation’s largest yogurt companies, began arguing among themselves.

articles.headline: Your Credit Score May Soon Look Better
articles.snippet: The three major credit bureaus will eliminate tax liens and civil judgments from the information they collect, starting July 1.
articles.abstract: The three major credit bureaus will eliminate tax liens and civil judgments from the information they collect, starting July 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: About 12 million people will get a lift in their credit scores next month as the national credit reporting agencies wipe from their records two major sources of negative information about borrowers: tax liens and civil judgments.

articles.headline: Justices to Hear Case on Religious Objections to Same-Sex Marriage
articles.snippet: A Colorado baker who refused to create a wedding cake for a gay couple is appealing a discrimination ruling, citing the First Amendment.
articles.abstract: A Colorado baker who refused to create a wedding cake for a gay couple is appealing a discrimination ruling, citing the First Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear an appeal from a Colorado baker with religious objections to same-sex marriage who had lost a discrimination case for refusing to create a cake to celebrate such a union.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Takes Up Travel Ban Case, and Allows Parts to Go Ahead
articles.snippet: In a partial win for President Trump, the court said a limited travel ban could take effect, and agreed to take a case with implications for presidential power.
articles.abstract: In a partial win for President Trump, the court said a limited travel ban could take effect, and agreed to take a case with implications for presidential power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court cleared the way on Monday for President Trump to prohibit the entry of some people into the United States from countries he deems dangerous, but the justices imposed strict limits on Mr. Trump’s travel ban while they examine the scope of presidential power over the border.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Products at Center of London Fire Faced Tougher Rules in U.S.
articles.snippet: The manufacturers, Arconic and Whirlpool, are widely expected to be central players in litigation over the fire.
articles.abstract: The manufacturers, Arconic and Whirlpool, are widely expected to be central players in litigation over the fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two products that played a major role in the deadly inferno in London had been assailed for their fire risks and faced tighter restrictions in the United States.
